rulings.title: Fasting Rules (All Madhabs)
items: Fasting means not eating, drinking, or doing anything that breaks your fast from Fajr to Maghrib.
You must make the intention (niyyah) before Fajr for it to count.
Swallowing food, drink, or anything through the mouth or nose breaks the fast.
Deliberate vomiting breaks the fast (Hanafi: if it’s a mouthful).
If you forget and eat, your fast is still valid — just stop immediately.

rulings.title: Who Doesn't Have to Fast?
items: Young children (before puberty)
Elderly people who cannot physically fast (must feed a poor person per day)
Sick people — they can make up missed fasts later
Travelers (if it’s difficult) — they can also make up the fasts later

rulings.title: Qada and Kaffarah
items: If you miss a fast for a valid reason (travel, sickness), just make it up later (Qada).
If you break your fast without excuse, you must fast 60 continuous days (Kaffarah) or feed 60 poor people (Hanafi).
Shafi‘i: Kaffarah is only for intentional intercourse during the fast; other breaks require Qada only.

rulings.title: Zakat Basics
items: You must own a minimum amount (called *nisab*) for one full lunar year to pay zakat.
If your money is equal to 87.48g of gold or 612.36g of silver, you must pay 2.5% of it.
Zakat is given to the poor, orphans, and others in need.
You cannot give zakat to your parents, children, or spouse.

rulings.title: Zakat at Eid
items: Zakat al-Fitr is given before Eid prayer to help the poor enjoy Eid.
Shafi‘i: Must be given in food (e.g. rice, wheat).
Hanafi: Can be given in money.
Required for every Muslim (including babies) if you can afford it.

rulings.title: General Rules
items: Earning money is halal as long as the work is halal (not gambling, selling alcohol, etc).
Cheating, lying, or deceiving people in business is haram.
Working with interest (riba) is haram — this includes charging or paying it.
Selling things that harm others (e.g., drugs, alcohol, fake items) is not allowed.

rulings.title: Simple Business Guidelines
items: Buyer and seller must agree clearly — no tricks.
Don't sell something you don't own yet.
If there's a problem with the product, tell the buyer.
All contracts must be free from major uncertainty (gharar).

rulings.title: Using Social Media
items: Don’t share haram content (music, gossip, immodesty).
Avoid wasting too much time scrolling — use your time wisely.
Online arguments and mocking others is not allowed.
Guard your modesty even online — what you post reflects your character.

rulings.title: Being a Muslim at School
items: It’s allowed to attend regular school as long as you avoid haram things.
You should pray on time, even during school (ask for permission respectfully).
Respecting teachers, classmates, and rules is part of good Islamic character.
Studying hard is a form of worship (if you do it for a good purpose).

rulings.title: General Guidelines
items: Clothes should be modest, not tight or see-through.
Boys should cover from navel to knees; girls should cover their whole body except face and hands (at minimum).
Imitating people who dress immodestly is discouraged.
Don’t wear things with offensive or haram images (e.g., music bands, inappropriate cartoons).
